Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Low-energy High-speed Optical Interconnects for Quantum Computers
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to improve interconnects between low-temperature quantum computing systems and the end users by using optical signal transmission. This method provides an alternative to the current electric signal transmission lines, which are easily disturbed by thermal noise. The project will address the current technological challenge of combining, as a single information circuit, the quantum computing systems and high-speed optical information distribution networks. Specifically, the project will (i) enable significant increases to the data processing and transfer rates for the end user and (ii) reduce the overall power consumption of the system. The proposed innovation will potentially enable to shift the quantum computing paradigm from the current experimental stage to large-scale applications in industry including big data science, artificial intelligence, biotechnology and drag discovery, and financial forecasting, as well as national security by including robust quantum-encrypted communication and quantum sensing.

This I-Corps project will further develop optical interconnects for quantum computing. The proposed technology utilizes cavity polaritons, which are photons dressed with charges in a semiconductor optical microcavity and, unlike photons in vacuum or dielectrics, are extremely sensitive to electric fields. This enables re-routing, switching on and off the light by means of the electric pulses from the qubit readout system. The use of emergent two-dimensional excitonic materials such as transition metal chalcogenides helps to significantly increase the light-matter interactions and thereby to improve the stability of the data transfer protocol by increasing the working speed, lowering latency and reducing the power consumption in the system. The latter will allow mitigation of the cooling power constraints for maintaining the cryogenic quantum computing data-transfer module.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: CUNY New York City College of Technology
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

Performance_Institution.Name: CUNY New York City College of Technology

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes of the project include:
  1. Via the customer discovery during the reporting period, the group produces the evidence of the market fit for our proposed technology of quantum interconnects for quantum computers. The pain points of the existing business model and technology on the market have been identified via in-person and tele-interviews, including (a) burning need to increase the computational power of quantum computing to make them suitable for industrial applications; and (b) missing key technology component, which can provide this capability. It was justified via the customer discovery that our proposed technology is vital for addressing these burning needs, is challenging, and is demanded by the industry.
  2. The group identified the focus areas in the industry where our proposed technology makes the most essential impact, which are cybersecurity and information technology, quantum technology and sensing, materials science, biotechnology, and finance. This conclusion has been justified via the in-person and tele interviews with potential customers and defended in tele-meetings with the NSF instructors during the training phase of the project.

The team achieved the following:

  • One provisional patent was submitted to USPTO: G. Kolmakov and S. Raklyar, Provisional utility patent 63/045,094, filed 06/27/2020 at USPTO, ?Exciton Polariton Optical Interconnect for Quantum Computers and High-Speed Data Transfer?. Currently the team is closely working with CUNY?s Tech Commercialization Office to submit non-provisional patent for the technology by 6/20/2021.
  • A woman operated, woman owned (51% of shares) startup company Next Generation Quantum Corp (C-Corp) was established by Co-EL Raklyar (undergrad student, now PhD student at CUNY, Physics Program, Photonics track) and PI Kolmakov, https://www.ngq.io  
  • The team has submitted a proposal for NSF SBIR (proposal # 8117970, PI Shaina Raklyar).
  • Internal CUNY grant has been submitted (PI Kolmakov, Raklyar - senior personnel, $20k, May 2021, pending) for the production facility fee coverage for the technology development.

Educational impact and outcomes include:

  • Provided opportunity to PI Kolmakov to expand the physics curriculum at the Hispanic-Serving Institution by including findings and methods from the project to his PHYS 1441 University Physics I course.
  • Provided exposure on a broad undergraduate and graduate student community by public presentations based on the project findings and received training, specifically:
    • four (4) talented students, including three (3) undergraduate and one (1) graduate student, including three (3) female students, one (1) African-American student, and one (1) student of Hispanic origin, were trained in business lean-startup methodology and cutting-edge technology.

Dissemination of the results include:

  • Presentation of Co-EL Raklyar of our findings for undergraduate students at NYC College of Technology CUNY in November 2019 (in person) and May 2020 (online).
  • Online presentation of Raklyar for graduate students at the Graduate Center, the City University of New York.
  • Online presentation of the quantum computer advances and the planned business model for industry representatives at the CUNY Startup Accelerator at Baruch college CUNY, May 2020.
  • Online presentation of the business model for investors at MIT The Engine accelerator, Summer 2020.
  • Online presentation of Raklyar and Kolmakov of the poster at the Materials Research Society meeting (remote), 2021.
  • Presentation of Co-EL Raklyar of our findings at the review meeting of Army research office DoD in October 2019.
  • In person presentation of Co-EL Raklyar about the technology transfer and quantum technology for graduate students of the Physics Program at the Graduate Center of CUNY, Fall 2019.
  • Poster presentation by Co-EL Raklyar and PI Kolmakov on the topic of the developed technology at the Materials Research Society Fall Meeting, Boston, MA, December 2019.
  • Poster presentation by Co-EL Raklyar of the developed quantum technology for graduate and undergraduate students and faculty at the U.S./Middle East Conference on Photonics ? Photonics Initiative, Advanced Science Research Center CUNY Nov 2019.
  • Invited general talk of PI Kolmakov on the topic of the project at the Quantum Computing Institute at Oak Ridge National Lab in August 2019.

Last Modified: 06/09/2021
Modified by: German Kolmakov

The pain points of the existing business model and technology on the market have been identified via in-person and tele-interviews, including (a) burning need to increase the computational power of quantum computing to make them suitable for industrial applications; and (b) missing key technology component, which can provide this capability. The group identified the focus areas in the industry where our proposed technology makes the most essential impact, which are cybersecurity and information technology, quantum technology and sensing, materials science, biotechnology, and finance.
